conventiondeclaration.citation: Describing Archives: A Content Standard, Second Edition

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday July 24, 2019 at 13:47

did.abstract: John Wiley was born in Flatbush, Long Island on October 4th, 1808. He is the son of Charles Wiley, the influential printer who founded John Wiley Sons, now known as just Wiley. John Wiley would start working at the company upon the death of his father in 1826. Over his tenure, the company would go through several name changes. First was Wiley, Lane Co., then Wiley Putnam, and then John Wiley. Wiley died in East Orange, New Jersey, on February 21st, 1891. Collection consists of a Pew Deed for John Wiley on October 16th, 1848. Additional materials are correspondences related to John Wiley and how the deed ended up in the possession of Edward P. Hamiliton. He received if from Stanley U. North of the General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches. Also included is a correspondence between Corinne M. Nordquist, former CLA Librarian, and Edward P. Hamilton.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted and open to the public.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Items in this collection are subject to U.S. Copyright Law. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine the copyright status of collection items and to secure any permissions necessary for their reproduction and publication. Requests for permission to publish material must be discussed with the archivist or librarian.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], in the John Wiley pew deed, 1844, 1964, RG5404. The Congregational Library & Archives, Boston, MA.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collection was processed by William McCarthy in June 2019, using DACS second edition.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: John Wiley was born in Flatbush, Long Island on October 4th, 1808. He is the son of Charles Wiley, the influential printer who founded John Wiley & Sons, now known as just Wiley. John Wiley would start working at the company upon the death of his father in 1826. Over his tenure, the company would go through several name changes. First was Wiley, Lane & Co., then Wiley & Putnam, and then John Wiley. Wiley died in East Orange, New Jersey, on February 21st, 1891.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of a Pew Deed for John Wiley on October 16th, 1848. Additional materials are correspondences related to John Wiley and how the deed ended up in the possession of Edward P. Hamiliton. He received if from Stanley U. North of the General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches. Also included is a correspondence between Corinne M. Nordquist, former CLA Librarian, and Edward P. Hamilton.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in chronological order.
